description: Techniques to make your React applications faster: Memoization, Lazy Loading, and Code Splitting.

slides.title: Why Performance Matters
slides.content:
# Speed = User Experience üöÄ

React is fast by default, but complex apps can become sluggish.

Common issues:
- **Wasted Renders:** Components updating when they don't need to.
- **Large Bundle Size:** Downloading unused code.
- **Blocking the Main Thread:** Heavy calculations.

slides.title: Code Splitting
slides.content:
# Code Splitting ‚úÇÔ∏è

Don't ship one giant `bundle.js`.

Split your code so users only download what they need.

Most common way: Route-based splitting using `React.lazy`.

```jsx
const Profile = React.lazy(() => import('./Profile'));
```

slides.title: React Profiler
slides.content:
# The Profiler üïµÔ∏è

Use the **React DevTools** "Profiler" tab to record interaction.

It shows:
- Which components rendered.
- Why they rendered (e.g., "props changed").
- How long it took.

This is the #1 tool for debugging specific slowness.

slides.title: Virtualization
slides.content:
# Virtual Lists üìú

Rendering 10,000 items in a DOM list is slow.

Use "Virtualization" (or "Windowing") to only render the items currently visible in the viewport.

Popular library: `react-window` or `react-virtualized`.

slides.title: Throttling & Debouncing
slides.content:
# Event Optimization ‚è±Ô∏è

Don't handle every single event if they happen fast (e.g., scroll, resize, typing).

- **Debounce:** Wait until user stops typing to Search.
- **Throttle:** Only fire scroll event once every 100ms.

slides.content:
# Recap: Performance üéì

Make it snappy.

- **Render less:** `React.memo`.
- **Compute less:** `useMemo`.
- **Load less:** Code Splitting (`React.lazy`).
- **Debug:** Use the Profiler.
